I had watched this video in the past, back when it was posted last year, and just found myself stumbling upon it again today, after having watched your new video about interviewing Barack Obama (also amazing, BTW, congratulations). The thing is, between then and now I found out I'm going to be a dad for the first time, and that gave me a completely different perspective watching the video again. Not only did I learn something here (the three blood vessels in the umbilical cord, for once), but it also made me feel a little more comfortable about this huge tiny thing that is about to change my life forever - I'll get to learn and have amazing new experiences with it, and that is wonderful.

So I wanted to thank you for taking the time to make videos like this one and being so open about the way you seem to cultivate great relationships with your family. Everything, from the t-shirt you were wearing at the hospital to the way you included your other children in the experience of having a new member added to the family, was very inspiring to me, personally, and I'm sure it did the same for others.

Thank you, I really appreciate it!

Sorry Destin, you got the umbilical blood vessels' flow direction wrong: the two umbilical arteries carry the poorly oxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta, where the blood gives up carbon dioxide and receives oxygen from mother's blood, then that oxygenated blood returns via the single (large) umbilical vein to the fetus.

Oxygen is carried by haemoglobin (Hgb). In order to efficiently take oxygen from mother's Hgb the fetal Hgb, which is different from adult Hgb, has higher affinity for oxygen. After birth, the newborn normally switches to making adult Hgb.

Anyhow, congratulations to you, your wife, and family on the birth of your new daughter!

Of course I do have to correct you on the statement about contractions. From the context clue of the relative calm of your wife I'm assuming that it was fairly early in labor. Nearly all contractions actually don't do much to "push the baby out". A significant portion of them are to dilate the cervix. It's only during the transition phase, when the cervix is dilated fully that the body 'transitions' into the  pushing type contractions. Which is relatively short compared to the whole of labor, as I'm sure you know. :p

Congratulations on your beautiful baby girl. Just a little bit more amazing biology for you. over the first few days of life your baby girls umbilical arteries will shrink down inside her and turn into ligaments! They are called a range of things like hypogastric arteries, hypogastric ligaments and just the normal umbilical arteries. This is due the peripheral pressure when your little girl is breathing! At the same time there is a little vessel in her called the ductus venosus, this is where the liver connects to the inferior vena cava. This then turns shuts off into a liagment also! Fascinating stuff! Love your work Destin!

When my son was born, he had a Patent Ductus Arteriosus, which means the valve you speak of, the Parent Ductus (which, by the way, it responsible for shunting blood away from the lungs, because in the womb, the lungs aren't used to oxygenate the blood) didn't close.  He had to have his PDA closed surgically at 7 months old.  Not a fun process to go through, we were extremely lucky though - we were 3 week from my son needing open heart, but luckily the FDA approved a procedure in time so he could have it done by cath instead of open heart.

You have gotten some details wrong about the umbilical artery and umbilical vein.

Umbilical artery: You are right that there are two of them; however the umbilical artery doesn't "supply blood to the baby", in fact the two arteries actually deliver deoxygenated blood from the baby to the placenta. 

Umbilical vein, on the other hand, receives oxygenated blood from the mother's placenta and deliver it to the heart and the rest of the body. 

The confusion with the nomenclature can be clarified when you remember that an artery delivers blood flow away from the heart, while a vein delivers the blood towards the heart.
